fulfil.translation[0].definitions[0].def: if you fulfil a hope, wish, or aim, you achieve the thing that you hoped for, wished for etc
fulfil.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: Visiting Disneyland has fulfilled a boyhood dream.
Being deaf hasn’t stopped Karen fulfilling her ambition to be a hairdresser.
It was then that the organization finally began to fulfill the hopes of its founders.
an analysis of how different countries are attempting to fulfill their political goals
fulfil.translation[0].definitions[1].def: to do or provide what is necessary or needed
fulfil.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: There is little doubt that the scheme fulfils a need for our community.
A good police officer is not fulfilling his role if he neglects this vital aspect.
Britain was accused of failing to fulfil its obligations under the EU Treaty.
Much of the electrical equipment failed to fulfill safety requirements.
fulfil.translation[0].definitions[2].def: if your work fulfils you, it makes you feel satisfied because you are using all your skills, qualities etc
fulfil.translation[1].definitions[0].def: if a hope, promise etc is fulfilled, the thing that you had hoped for, promised etc happens or is done
fulfil.translation[1].definitions[0].exa: Our aim is to fulfill our clients’ wishes as efficiently as possible.
She is striving to fulfil her ambition to be a fashion designer.
fulfil.translation[1].definitions[1].def: to supply the things that have been ordered
fulfil.translation[1].definitions[1].exa: a UK company that acquires goods from a Belgian supplier to fulfil an order from a German customer
fulfil.translation[1].definitions[2].def: to do the things that a contract says you must do
fulfil.translation[1].definitions[2].exa: The seller can fulfil his contract only by delivery of 500 tons of grain from the specified cargo.
The company is struggling to fulfill its contracts.
fulfil.translation[1].definitions[3].def: to reach a standard that is necessary, especially one that has been officially decided
fulfil.translation[1].definitions[3].exa: Much of the electrical equipment failed to fulfill safety requirements.
The rental contract sets out the conditions which the tenant is required to fulfil.
fulfil.translation[1].definitions[4].def: to provide something that someone needs
fulfil.translation[1].definitions[4].exa: The service will run initially for three months but may become permanent if it fulfils a need.
It is essential that the agency only sends us applicants who fulfil our requirements.
fulfil.translation[1].definitions[5].def: to do the things a person, organization, or machine must do or is expected to do
fulfil.translation[1].definitions[5].exa: He fulfilled his role as manager very effectively.
Robots fulfil many dull and tedious jobs on the production line.
fulfil.translation[1].definitions[6].def: to achieve what you were hoping to do
fulfil.translation[1].definitions[6].exa: The managers must decide on the policies and priorities that help the company to fulfil its aims.
There are major goals which businesses fulfill such as maximising the return on capital.
fulfil.translation[1].definitions[7].def: if your work fulfils you, it makes you feel satisfied because you are using all your skills or qualities
fulfil.translation[1].definitions[7].exa: I have rarely seen a person so fulfilled by hiswork.
fulfil.translation[1].definitions[8].def: to be as successful as you could possibly be
fulfil.translation[1].definitions[8].exa: We are confident that the new sales manager will fulfil his potential.
